Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative research: Is Anthropocene sedimentation in valley bottoms a geologically significant event?
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical description of the project's broader significance and importance

Recent research in geomorphology, the study of Earth's surface and the processes that shape it, has found that human modification of land in the northeastern U.S. over the past few centuries has resulted in large volumes of sediment being eroded from hillsides and deposited in valleys along rivers and streams. Prior research has suggested that this sediment transfer is the most important modification of Earth's landscape in tens of thousands of years. This project will evaluate the significance of these deposits on a regional scale by carefully measuring them in representative field locations and then using newly available high-resolution topographic data to extrapolate the findings to whole watersheds and regions. Knowledge of how human activities have contributed to landscape change is a prerequisite for informed land-management and restoration decisions. To ensure broad communication of project findings, the researchers will interact with policy makers, planners, government agencies, and non-profit organizations interested in stream and wetland conservation. This project also will include strong opportunities for student research, since the collaborating institutions are heavily invested in undergraduate education as a priority.

Technical description of the project

Recent global sedimentation studies demonstrate that rates of erosion due to human activities exceed the amount of sediment delivered to the oceans by rivers. At the same time, field-based studies at the channel to watershed scale have found large quantities of sediment stored in valley bottoms during the past few centuries. This project will bridge the gap between global and watershed-based approaches by quantifying the amount of Anthropocene (recent, human related) sediment stored in valley bottoms of the northeastern United States, and then comparing this amount to published volumes and timescales of (1) erosion from the landscape, and (2) deposition in reservoirs, lakes, and estuaries along the Atlantic margin. The research will use high-resolution topographic data to map the extent and thickness of this fill over large spatial areas (1,000-10,000 square km), and will test these methods using fieldwork (mapping, coring, geophysical data collection, sediment sampling and dating) in key watersheds. A central goal is to evaluate the extent to which sediment storage in the unglaciated mid-Atlantic region applies in the glaciated, less-studied New England region, where upland soils are thin, sediment sources are generally localized to glacial deposits, and large natural lakes and wetlands provide terrestrial accommodation space. The results of the project will help resolve the discrepancy between erosion and deposition rates at small spatial (watershed) and temporal (decadal to centennial) scales versus the rates that occur globally and over geological time.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Recent research in geomorphology, the study of Earth’s surface and the processes that shape it, has found that human alterations of land surfaces in the eastern U.S. over the past few centuries has resulted in the erosion and translocation of soils from hillslopes to valley bottom storage. Previous studies suggested that this movement and storage of sediment, induced by European settlement of the New World, is the most important modification of Earth’s landscape in tens of thousands of years of recent Earth History. This project seeks to test whether these deposits represent a geologically significant event on the regional scale by carefully mapping them in the field and then using newly available high-resolution topographic datasets to scale up our findings to whole watersheds and regions.

In the eastern US, widespread, intense alteration of landscapes began with the arrival of European settlers and forest clearing during the late 17th and early 18th centuries. In the mid-Atlantic region, it is estimated that these early agricultural practices led to ~15 cm of soil erosion, and that the building of thousands of mill dams in valley bottoms acted as efficient sediment retention basins. The pervasiveness of such historical valley-bottom deposits is less well documented in New England. Both regions have a similar history and intensity of European settlement, but glacier advances during the Ice Ages stripped New England of most of it’s soil, leaving little of it to erode during the intense phase European settlement. In this NSF-funded research project we test the hypothesis that agriculture-induced sedimentation in valley bottoms was greater in the mid-Atlantic than New England because of thicker soils. We test this hypothesis using geological field studies, radiocarbon dating, and GIS-based mapping in three watersheds in each region: northeastern US (NEUS) and the Mid-Atlantic Region (MAR). We determined the volume of sediment storage by mapping valley bottom sediment terraces using lidar (light detection and ranging) digital elevation models, then dividing these volumes by drainage area to obtain basin-wide yields of soil erosion.

In general, the hypothesis that historical valley-bottom sedimentation is a geologically significant event is supported by this study, especially in the Mid-Atlantic Region. Valley bottom storage indicates a few cm of region-wide erosion of hillslope soils, and likely represents only a fraction of soil eroded during historical time. Additional sediment was transported into estuaries and lakes, both during the early period of land clearing or after dams breached. 

In Pennsylvania, we used aerial lidar acquisitions from April 2008 and December 2014 to produce high-resolution digital elevation models (DEMs) for Lancaster County (2549 km2) in the southeastern PA piedmont. We produced a DEM difference map for the 6.6-yr interval between lidar acquisition dates, calculated errors based on instrumental uncertainty and surface roughness, and then used observed differences between the two images to detect change in valley bottom character, noting whether there was measurable erosion or deposition, and further calculated volumes of change. 

Our results indicate that no bank erosion occurs where historic milldams are unbreached. In stark contrast, where milldams are recently breached (within the last decade), stream banks experienced large amounts of bank retreat and sediment erosion. In one example watershed we calculate ~45 m3of streambank erosion per km of stream length per year. The estimated suspended sediment load from bank erosion is comparable to EPA Total Maxzimum Daily Load (TMDL) estimates, although most of this TMDL load is mistakenly attributed to modern land use, specifically soil erosion from farms, and not to streambank erosion of historic “legacy” sediments as found in this study. 

This work has implications for understanding the sources of sediment and nutrient loads to streams in the Eastern US, and will inform state and federal policy makers and restoration practitioners on where stream and wetland restoration practices will have the greatest effect and positive benefit for reducing sediment loads to downstream waterways.
